 Am I correct in saying that Hinduism recognizes a single supreme divine being taking the form of a Trinity, and that this being has many lesser manifestations within the Hindu pantheon?

 There is a form of the Trinity in Hinduism. However, the supreme being exists in more than just a trinity. The supreme being (Atman) actually exists in everything. The Trinity is simply a subsection of all the existences of the Atman. The Trinity of Brahma (can be considered the creator), Visnu (the preserver) and Siva (the recycler) was more formally recognized and given importance in later Hinduism though. There is mention of Visnu in the Rig Vedas (the oldest recognized script of Hinduism), but he is not regarded in the same esteem as Indra and others are.

 I will refer to them as aspects, because IMO it better reflects their role. In Hinduism, there is one God (in the ultimate God sense). He is Brahman (not to be confused with Brahma). Brahman is the universe itself; he is everything and everything is him (pantheist theology). However, even the greatest of the aspects has trouble comprehending his existense, for Brahman is infinite. The ones that Hindus worship are aspects. They include (but not limited to :) ): Brahma, Visnu, Siva, Parvati, Lakshmi, Ganesha, Muruga, Krisna, Rama (the list goes on). Many aspects are related; they belong to a devine "family tree" so to say. Also, Krisna, for example, is actually Visnu incarnate. So yeah, the number of "gods" is big.  It is true that the cow is considered "Aghanya," or that which may not be slaughtered. However, this was a cultural devopment and not a religious one. In fact, during the time of the Vedas (well, during the time in which they were conceived), the Indus civilizations ate plenty of beef. Vegetarianism and anti-beef eating more specifically arose due the the start of Buddhism and Jainism, which condemned (mostly) the eating of meat. Also, in those days, it was cultural norm to prepare a feast of the most prized animal of your belonging (usually the stud bull) when an important guest came to visit. This practice, however, kept decreasing the quality of the herd. Therefore, to save atleast some of the herd, people rendered cows as being a taboo to eat.
 
 There are many Vedic stories which entail beef eating. In fact, there is one where five men eat an entire cow in one meal. The confusion with "cow worship" being in religion occured because of linguistical problems. The Vedas are written in Sanskrit, a language atleast as old as Latin and Greek, and thought by most to be even older. There are two forms of Sanskrit, Vedic Sanskrit, the Sanskrit in which the Vedas were written, and Classical Sanskrit, the Sanskrit we know today. Vedic Sanskrit is much more complicated than its classical brother (Classical Sanskrit is grammatically more difficult than Russian and German, IMO). In Vedic Sanskrit, "goh" means both bovine and light. Therefore, Protector of the "Goh" in Vedic Sanskrit actually means Protector of the Light. However, in Classical Sanskrit, "Goh" only means cow, giving Protector of the "Goh" an odd meaning. But, following Vedic Sankrit, the Protector of the "Goh" was not a herdsman, but actually a divine being. Similarily, there are many other Vedic stories in praise of "Goh" itself; thus, the myth of cow worship was born.
 
 Therefore, the "sacredness" of the cow was actually due to changes in cultural trends and linguistic misinterpretation, NOT as a result of religious doctrine.

 There are two catagories of scripture. Shriti is that which is heard, but can be interpreted as that which is discovered. The other is Smriti, or that which is remembered or told. Shriti is considered unchangeable, because it is a record of observation. Smriti can be altered slightly to match the times. Smriti is second to Shriti; therefore, due to the times in which they are comprehended, if Smriti contradicts Shriti, Shriti is given authority. It should also be noted that moral code in Hinduism falls into Smriti; therefore, morals can change in accordance with the era in Hinduism, following the idea that people define morals.
 
 In regards to Shriti:
 
 1) Vedas
 There are four Vedas that lay the foundation for Hinduism: The Rig Veda (the oldest scripture; relates both philosophy and hyms), Sama Veda (the Veda for hyms only. Many hyms here are duplicates of the hyms in the Rig Veda), Yajur Veda (the Veda for rituals. Describes proper ways to perform rituals), and Artharva Veda (the Veda of metaphysics. Much younger than the other Vedas).
 
 2) Upanishads
 The philosophy in the Vedas are paraphrased in another series of scriptures, the Upanishads. Most Upanishads are in the form of a conversation between teacher and student. For example,
 

 1. The Teacher says: 'If you think I know it (Brahman) well, then you know surely but little, what is that form of Brahman known, it may be, to you?'
 
 2. The Pupil says: 'I do not think I know it well, nor do I know that I do not know it. He among us who knows this, he knows it, nor does he know that he does not know it.
 
 3. 'He by whom it (Brahman) is not thought, by him it is thought; he by whom it is thought, knows it not. It is not understood by those who understand it, it is understood by those who do not understand it.
 
 4. 'It is thought to be known (as if) by awakening, and (then) we obtain immortality indeed. By the Self we obtain strength, by knowledge we obtain immortality.
 
 5. 'If a man know this here, that is the true (end of life); if he does not know this here, then there is great destruction (new births). The wise who have thought on all things (and recognised the Self in them) become immortal, when they have departed from this world.'
 

 
 
 In regards to Smriti
 
 1) Epics
 The major epics in Hinduism are the Mahabharata and the Raamayanam. They both detail major wars in 'Indian history' (the truth of these epics is questionable).
 
 2) Codes of Law
 The major code of law is "The Law of Manu." However, since it is Smriti, it must be concurrent with the times to be considered truth. "The Law of Manu" contradicts much moral institutions of today, so it is largely disregarded.
 
 3) Puraanas
 These are sacred romances.
 
 4) Darshanas
 These are philosophical treatises.
 
 5) Aagamas
 These are sectarian scriptures.
